comments.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째 1. Compile the following code: // ============= START OF EXAMPLE =========== // ==ClosureCompiler== // @compilation_level ADVANCED_OPTIMIZATIONS // ==/ClosureCompiler== function buggyReturn() { return { a:"", b:"34234" }; } alert(buggyReturn().b); // ============= END OF EXAMPLE =========== This code causes the following compilation errors: // ============= START OF ERRORS ========== Number of errors: 2 JSC_PARSE_ERROR: Parse error. missing ; before statement at line 5 character 7 b:"34234" ^ JSC_PARSE_ERROR: Parse error. missing } after function body at line 8 character 23 // ============= END OF ERRORS ========== What is the expected output? What do you see instead? 째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째 In my oppinion the compiler should not do automatic semicolon insertion and cause an error instead! function noMorebuggyReturn() { return { a:"", b:"34234" }; } What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째째 I am using the current version of the online compiler: http://closure-compiler.appspot.com/home

Try typing that code into a browser. This is exactly how the browser would interpret 
you code. So the compiler error is correct.
